title: Cognizant hit with class-action lawsuits over TriZetto data breach
executive_summary: Cognizant Technology Solutions and its healthcare claims subsidiary, TriZetto Provider Solutions (TPS), are facing multiple class-action lawsuits in the U.S. following a significant data breach. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
Allegations focus on delayed discovery of the breach and slow notification to affected individuals, increasing potential harm. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
what_happened: Unauthorized access to TriZetto systems reportedly began as early as November 2024, but Cognizant did not discover the intrusion until October 2, 2025. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Hackers accessed and compromised personal data, including Social Security numbers, financial account information, and home addresses. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Multiple class-action suits were filed in federal courts in New Jersey and Missouri, alleging negligence in data protection and delayed breach notification. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
who_is_affected: Individuals in the United States whose personal data was processed by TriZetto’s systems. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
Residents of multiple states including Arizona and California whose information was exposed. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
Healthcare providers, insurers, and clients relying on TriZetto for claims processing, due to reputational and operational impacts.
attack_flow: Initial unauthorized access to the TriZetto network. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
Prolonged undetected compromise of sensitive data systems. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
Eventual discovery of the breach nearly a year later. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
Filing of class-action lawsuits alleging delayed notification and insufficient protection.
business_impact: Legal liability from multiple class-action lawsuits. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
Financial costs associated with litigation, potential settlements, and any required remediation.
Reputational damage affecting customer trust, particularly in healthcare IT services. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}
Potential regulatory scrutiny and compliance challenges.
risk_reason: Delayed detection and notification of a breach involving highly sensitive personal data increases the risk of identity theft, fraud, and legal liability, making this a material risk event. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}
what_usually_goes_wrong: Insufficient real-time monitoring and detection capability. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}
Delayed or incomplete breach notification to affected individuals. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}
Failure to implement robust data security controls or to encrypt sensitive personal information.

immediate: Notify affected individuals promptly and provide guidance on monitoring for identity theft.
Engage independent forensic and legal teams to assess root cause and compliance obligations.
short_term: Implement advanced intrusion detection and response (IDR) systems.
Review and strengthen data protection controls, including encryption and access logging.
long_term: Establish continuous security monitoring and incident response workflows.
Conduct regular third-party security audits and penetration tests.
Review governance and compliance programs related to breach reporting.

what_this_does_not_mean: That all Cognizant services or clients were breached — this relates specifically to the TriZetto incident. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}
That fraud has already occurred for every affected individual — the lawsuits address potential future risks.

signs: Unusual external access logs or previous anomalous login attempts.
Notifications from credit monitoring services about potential misuse of personal data.
alerts: New reports of identity theft tied to compromised data.
Regulatory inquiries or enforcement actions related to breach disclosure.
